messages.message:
<!here> we were having discussions on character level confidence for Microsoft OCR
(like the way we have for Abby) — where are we on that?

Msft Read api does not support any character level confidence, all confidence reporting is _word_ level confidence.

The Read 2.0 API (which we are currently using) only tells us if a word is marked as "low" confidence.

The Read 3.0 API gives a numneric confidence score but it is still at the word level.   We are currently working to integrate with the 3.0 api, and working with msft team to reduce resource requirements for running the containers (they are way too high right now).
any timeline for that?

I can finish integrating with 3.0 API by end of the month.  If its high priority i can push it sooner.

Msft does not have a good timeline for improving the resource requirements though.
here are two things:
@Aaron Tami can we access the word level confidence today (specifically for BofA marketplace solutions)
[1] can we surface low confidence with 2.0 at the word level in our ibocr
[2] can all marketplace apps access it?
[3] can we create a placeholder for numeric score which could be null
We already are surfacing the "low" confidence from the 2.0 api into our ibdocs
then [2] should be doable
can we have marketplace apps surface it for fields that have words with low accuracy
this would require no platform change
@Balaram we can talk through this tonight to see if we can embed in 1040 and W2
i can add the placeholder for the numerical word confidence score.  I'll also try to expedite the msft 3.0 support and get it ready by next week so you can start playing with it
word of warning tho, it will be quite tough to deploy to customers, each pod has a 12-16 GB memory requirement
this is for 3.0, right? not 2.0 - assume that BofA already has 2.0?
yes 2.0 is already deployed to BofA and the "low" confidence indicator is already available in the ibdoc
let me find an example
https://instabase.com/tami/my-repo/fs/Instabase%20Drive/ocr-testing/ocr-ari/run_tami/2020-11-11-18%3A41%3A10/565a6e50-eeac-496c-9d31-a4e2ad420554/out/s1_process_files/LOWCONFIDENCE.png.ibdoc
can the Marketplace team utilize it in all extractions

I'm not sure, what else would be needed for them to be able to utilize this aside from it being in the ibdoc? I know we have a refiner function to get confidence scores for a word, i think this would just be included in that data structure
let me look into this
actually we might need to add this to that
+ @Aaron Vontell
he might know — I think we did provenance
where we used this

There is a function to get confidence score for the entire record. I am meeting with Aaron Vontell tomorrow. Also had a chat with Jonathan.

https://www.instabase.com/docs/reference/refiner/ocr-functions/
Yeah there are validation functions and functions to get this info out of a provenance-tracked value
One sec I will find the link to the docs, those docs dont include them
https://www.instabase.com/docs/reference/refiner/confidence-functions/

Here are all the functions that are currently disabled, we disabled them because customers misunderstood what OCR confidence meant: https://github.com/instabase/instabase/blob/master/shared-utils/py-utils/data-api-utils/src/py/instabase/data_api_utils/_sheet/confidence_fns.py#L1297-L1307
We can re-enable and also copy-paste as UDFs if needed
Those are probably most relevant to what you all are looking for
what was the misunderstanding, @Aaron Vontell?

Sorry was in a meeting - This started to surface at C1, and it was for 3 reasons:
1. The confidence score and “unsure” concepts / meanings differ from engine to engine. In some cases it can be a probability of that character, in some cases it can be a non-probability score, etc…
2. (This is the main thing that confused them) the confidence score and “unsure” flag have really no correlation - you can have a score of 0.05 and still be sure about the character, and then a situation with a confidence of 0.95 and unsure would be marked as true
3. Low confidences and high confidences aren’t often useful - you can have entire words where each character is marked with a confidence of 0, but the word is still extracted correctly. 
(Note that these anecdotes are from before we used Microsoft OCR, their results may be different)
So in the end, we disabled the functions that would allow customers to get raw confidence results, because we found that they were not that useful. Given those anecdotes, for instance, if the logic from the customer was to “mark as needing validation any result that has an average OCR confidence of less than 0.75”, there isn’t a very good correlation between those results and actual OCR errors
Happy to elaborate more if needed!
I know @Justin has opinions on this as well
More than happy to re-evaluate our thinking on this and expose those functions by the way - but if we do, we should make sure to consider how to document it

I feel strongly on @Aaron Vontell's second point
> (This is the main thing that confused them) the confidence score and “unsure” flag have really no correlation - you can have a score of 0.05 and still be sure about the character, and then a situation with a confidence of 0.95 and unsure would be marked as true
Confidence is a rather useless metric that only placates risk teams but doesn't actually help users achieve their business goals.

If we start supporting more granular confidence and make it part of instabase, rather than part of the native OCR engine we could be in for a lot of trouble. For example something that is wrong but has a high confidence, we don't want to be on the hook for that.

I also think it adds a whole new layer of complexity and friction to achieving STP, where if confidence is used as a filter our numbers will inevitably only go down as more data is filtered out
let’s all chat to discuss this
@nakul @Justin @Kerry @Aaron Vontell, @Aaron Tami — add more people if needed
+ @hannah and @Sara Niforatos
we have a meeting at 5-530 pt
^ 5p PT :slightly_smiling_face:
@Justin @nakul can you please add @Anant to the 5 PM meeting you are referencing?FYI @hannah
I added @Anant and @hannah
Saw that, thank you !
